Misuse of the passing lane is a large contributor to traffic congestion. It forces everyone to slow down and use their brakes, which causes the chain effect leading to grid lock. It's ok to speed up beyond the limit to safely and quickly pass another car, then immediately move back into the travel lane. This encourages traffic to speed up and keep moving, rather than braking and slowing down.

The problem, and solution, lies in urban planning, not in motorist behavior. American cities are not built to support pedestrians or public transport systems. We live in cities that are basically parking lots surrounded by suburbs. A lot of cities around the world have been successful in creating environments in which people can walk and public transport runs efficiency and is accessible. Such cities are common in Europe: Copenhagen, Amsterdam, Paris, basically every large European city is very good quality. Outside of Europe, Buenos Aires and Tokyo are also good examples. I recommend everyone check these places out in Google Maps and street view. Notice how much of the land space is dedicated to parking lots, and compare that to American cities. Until America starts building good quality cities, its people will be trapped in traffic forever. Most Americans have to drive a car just to buy a toothpaste.

The traffic oscillations are pretty easy to explain. The drivers are trying to obey rules about their driving and adjust their driving to suit i.e. it is a negative feedback system. However there is a delay in their reaction and for a certain frequency of changes that delay is equal to 180° meaning that the feedback is positive. As the number increases the gain of the system needs to increase i.e. the drivers need to make more extreme compensations and the system oscillates.

Interesting facts.
Some practical issues to deal with when it comes to taking transit: there are cities where people would rather get stuck in traffic for an hour than getting on a bus or a subway during a busy rush hour. This is because you at least you have some place to sit. On a busy subway, you are very likely to be standing during the entire trip. Unless they make local transit more passenger friendly by giving everybody a comfortable seat, there will always be people who prefer to drive around. The other issue is that local transit isn't always the fastest way to get across town depending on the route you're taking. In some cases, a car can go on a local freeway while a bus is restricted to local roads and stopping every few minutes to pick up passengers.

As a person who drives twice a week in Lima, a pretty crowded city in South America, I can say that this makes sense. Accidents make twice or three times more traffic than they should for these reasons:
1. Drivers slow down to see what happened. This, surprisingly, can as well create traffic on the contrary lane in a highway (funny, right?).
2. Drivers who happen to be on the accident lane want to get out of the lane as soon as they notice it, cutting off other cars, who will have to slow down or stop completely or resort to cutting off the cars on the other lane, so it becomes a triple chain of cut-offs.
3. Cutting off can, of course, create mini accidents like bumps, where drivers will have to stop to see if their car has been damaged, hence adding more traffic.
4. In addition, being cut off enrages certain drivers, who might want to do the same and, in order to achieve that, they will be cutting off other drivers and create another chain of cut-offs.
5. Me first! The worst of all.

Think of it this way. In the example of cars driving in a circle, over time the inconsistencies in speed eventually add up to traffic coming to a complete stop. Lets say each fluctuation costs the flow of traffic 1mph of loss. If the cars start out going 60mph, it will take 60 fluctuations to get to 0mph. If they start at 30mph however then it would only take 30 fluctuations to get to 0mph. Now imagine if in the study all cars were told to go 30mph, except one driver was told to go 25mph. Instantly all cars are limited to 25mph, and the line of cars is that much closer to 0mph. That is what this video is telling us to do!

A lot of this is great theory. But as someone who up until recently, drove professionally, I can attest to a few additions and/or outright changes.
Yes, a majority of drivers really are stupid. They are in a constant state of going 10 mph under or over the speed limit, daydreaming, playing with something, talking on a phone, talking with their hands to a passenger, or looking at anything other than the road, just to name a few.
This is right in the sense that the best drivers are the ones who pay attention, set themselves apart from traffic, stay constant, and generally mind their own business.

Something else that a lot of people forget is that once out on any road, they are now a collective. An accident on one side of town now has an effect on the other side, and on highways as well as side streets.
Now, multiply that by all the accidents on the road at one time, road imperfections, lights which follow patterns of insanity, signs couter-productive to a logical flow of traffic, rubber-neckers who act as though they have never seen an accident or the police pull someone over, all the problems I mentioned previously plus the fact that everybody is subject to a range of every emotion which affects driving?
And frankly, I'm astounded we can get anywhere at all.

It's called the Accordion Effect. It's a function of the fact that action is always faster than reaction, and is made worse by widespread poor driving technique. In slowing traffic, the delayed reaction time of drivers farther back in line tends to eat up the space in front of them as traffic slows (especially if they were following too closely or not paying attention to begin with). That space becomes smaller and smaller until traffic comes to a dead stop, very much like an accordion compresses, then extends, compresses, etc.. When you get up to the spot and discover there was seemingly nothing there to cause the stop to begin with or the problem was entirely on the other side of the road ("rubber necking"), the Accordion Effect is what happened.

It's also made worse by two basic mistakes that many drivers make. They fail to keep their "eyes high" as is taught in many (most?) basic drivers ed classes but is soon forgotten (or never learned) by many drivers. So many drivers look no farther ahead than the back bumper of the car ahead of them (or less), so as traffic slows, it catches them by surprise. They also fail to increase their gaze/focus distance as their speed increases.

Many drivers also far overuse their brakes. In fact, brakes are the "go to" default crutch of marginal drivers. Something (anything) happens somewhere in front of them? BRAKE! About to make a lane change? BRAKE! Road not perfectly straight? BRAKE! Merging onto a highway? BRAKE! Confused about where they're going? BRAKE! Riding the bumper of the car ahead of them? BRAKE! Rushing up to a red light or stopped traffic that was visible for the last several thousand feet? BRAKE! Every few seconds for no apparent reason at all? BRAKE! On the other hand, drivers who use appropriate modulation of the gas peddle to manage their momentum (aka "speed averaging") combined with the "eyes high" technique to look far enough ahead of them to anticipate slowdowns or to increase speed slightly to make those green lights ahead, use their brakes 1/10th of the times of drivers who rely on their brakes as their primary control method. The eyes high/speed averaging technique is far more efficient, decreases wear on the vehicle, and helps prevent the needless compressing of traffic (Accordion Effect).

Driver behavior is one of the main reasons for traffic congestion on freeways or any other road with no traffic lights.

Drivers will slow down when passing next to stopped or slow traffic on a different lane. ( Especially visible on exits )

They will slow down on very shallow climbs reducing speed by even 20 mph compared to the previous speed.

They will slow down when the shoulder of the road slims down although the lane widths remain the same. When the divider is around 1 - 2 feet from the lanes, drivers will slow down the most.

Drivers will move slower the fewer lanes a road has.

Drivers will slow down when another enters their lane ahead of them even when this other car is ahead by 4 to 5 cars distance and moving faster.

Some drivers will slow down when changing lanes.

Traffic will slow down when 4 or more drivers at a time have to change lanes on sections of a road. Especially visible on exits or entry points. The problem worsens when an entry point merges into the same lane as an exit that is 50 to 150 yards ahead.

A similar behavior happens with entry points merging into the same lane within 100 to 200 yards of each other.

Some drivers will leave a 7 to 10 cars long distance in front of them during congestions, creating an obstacle. This will trigger the same behavior as before when multiple drivers change lanes to get in front or to get away from the obstacle driver. Meanwhile, the obstacle drive will slow down to keep the 7 to 10 cars long distance.

Of course these behaviors compound with one another, and multiple instances of the same behavior will occur on the same stretch of road.

Many other such behaviors occur but this comment is already too long.

Now, if YOU don't want to be stuck in traffic and overtake dozens of cars every minute:

- Use Google Maps navigation ALWAYS, its a life saver at routing you around accidents way ahead of time.
- Leave a distance so you can switch lanes effectively and see well ahead. Tailgating will jam you as soon as traffic breaks.
- Switch to lanes where cars are getting off the road as exits come up. Large spaces of open road form right after exits.
- Identify slow drivers early and don't get stuck behind them.
- Look at all your mirrors often and make sure you have an exit strategy to switch lane should yours begin to jam.
- Ambulances are like the star powerup in Mario Kart. If one is coming through get behind it and follow closely.
- Get the TomTom speed camera app if you are on Android.

As a tractor trailer driver, I tend to leave space around my vehicle as a buffer to fluctuations in traffic speeds. And once it's time to stop and go I will avoid shifting thru my gears to stay with the pack and instead create space for others to flow into. The same concept applies where traffic merges due to a lane closure or emergency equipment on the side of the road. When I see the first sign saying that x lane is closed ahead, I change lanes then, rather than like the majority, wait until the last possible moment--which is what causes the rest of traffic to slam on the brakes and cause the traffic jam.

1) If you don't wanna get stuck in traffic then don't go into traffic.

2) Don't go when everyone else goes into traffic. Spreading traffic out so there's a constant number of vehicles on a particular stretch of road means traffic won't grow and shrink as it currently does in the morning and evenings. That is, get rid of the normal working hours of 9 to 5 etc. Instead, if a constant number of people work at any given time of day you can completely eliminate traffic jams on the current infrastructure.

3) Spread out geographically. Sure, having your office in the middle of a city is great for ... reasons? But it's even better to have your office by a lake on the outskirts of a city where commuters can take a ring road rather than go straight through a city core. The same applies to anywhere else basically. Modern GPS units come with traffic density warnings, giving you alternative routes to take to circumvent bottlenecks.

4) Toyota making a zero emissions vehicle? What, is it going to be stationary and made of plant life or what?
There is no such thing as zero emissions. Just because you run a car on a battery and electric engine and thus not emitting CO2 doesn't mean you magically get the energy to recharge those batteries from nowhere. Let alone making the components of that vehicle.
Of course, one could argue that if you put solar panels on the vehicle and thus never recharge it then it would truly be a zero emissions vehicle. But have fun with that... You might as well walk.
EVERYTHING that is moving requires energy input to keep moving against gravity, resistance and other losses in the system. You can't have zero emissions if you need to insert energy into the system. SIMPLE.

Block driving is a common thing here in Belgium during the summer. Because if the weather is good, everybody wants to go to the sea... at the same time.
It happened to me once. Driving at the freeway and then a motorized cop drives ahead in the middle lane, making signs that we should not pass it and guiding us as one big block at 90 km/h moving forward (instead of the usual 120 km/h).
This system works, because the frontmost drivers of "the block" are too afraid to pass the motorized cop in terms of speed. As well as the "block driving" is announced on the radio on days when cops feel it needs to be implemented.
And as an FYI: the system is needed. Belgium and Holland are the top countries with a highly concentrated amount of traffic over its small country sizes. This often causes traffic jams where you can lose an hour or more.

in this ideal example we assume we have 100 participants. the value "being a good driver" will be measured in the goodness scale 1-10
10 drivers have a goodness of 1

the average driver therefor has a goodness value of (10*90 + 1*10) / 100 = 9.1

Ways to avoid traffic: Don't be traffic: carpool or take transit (especially with a dedicated ROW), if transit isn't an option, move to a place where transit is an option. While you're at it, move closer to your work, this might be more expensive, but your time is valuable too, people underestimate the value of their time, and choose to live in a cheaper bigger home farther away, while experiencing a decreased quality of life from spending so long traveling. And travel by bike. And travel off peak times. Now, I know EVERYONE has an excuse why they can't do this. And some, maybe even most, really can't make these types of changes. But many people could, and as pointed out, it only takes a small shift to make big changes in the traffic congestion.

Oh, and another thing, support smart growth plans, transit expansions, etc., that are designed to guide your region/local area into a denser smaller more sustainable area. These areas are inherently better for transportation.

Last thing, don't put too much focus on traffic. Here's an interesting question, would you rather spend 45 minutes commuting at rush hour, a trip that would take 20 minutes at midnight, or you would prefer a 2.5 hour commute at rush hour, that would take only 2.25 hours at midnight?

The first right? Nobody would prefer a 2.5 hour commute. And yet, focusing on traffic, the 2.5 hour commute sounds far better, because the traffic congestion is far less.

This is what cities have been doing in planning for a long time. But this is a mistake that leads to very long commute times.

Two comments:

1. "best driver" isn't defined. Since everybody defines how a "good" driver is, most people can indeed be right in that they're a better driver according to their own criteria. This is not strange at all. Define a "good driver" and then ask people if they're better than average at this, and you might see other results. Is a good driver purely defensive? Accommodating to other drivers? Strictly safe with huge margins? Great at handling their car at the limit? Sufficiently safe when driving fast? Avoiding risks at all cost? It's all a trade-off, and there is no definition.

2. Highest throughput on a highway is around 70km/h. At this point, flow is at a critical point. Any disturbance, of any kind, leads to lower throughput which will not fix itself until new cars are added at a lower rate than the flow rate. This typically means the flow is
collapsed by a small protuberance and it's then in a collapsed state until after rush hour.

"80 to 90% of drivers think they're better than the average driver, which is impossible" No, it's not. Suppose there are 10 drivers, and they each have a score from 1 to 10 to rate their driving skills. Say there's one with score 3 and 9 with score 8. The average score is (3 + 9*8) / 10 which is 75. 90% are above average, 10% is below average. All it takes is a lot of OK drivers and some really bad drivers for the 'impossible' to be the case.
